Influenza viral genomes are RNA, not DNA. They may have 7 or 8 RNA segments in their genome. When segments are mixed and matched between two viruses that is RECOMBINATION, not MUTATION! RNA proofreading enzymes are absent, and the RNA-dependent RNA transcriptase makes a single nucleotide insertion error roughly once per 10K nucleotides, which is approximately the total length of the viral RNA (it can be up to almost 50% longer). Thus, nearly every new influenza virus will contain a new single nucleotide mutation in its genome. Nevertheless, it is the recombination of genome segments that is the main reason why we need new influenza virus vaccines for each flu season.

Great video, but the process by which multiple flu strains infect an individual and give rise to new mutants, what’s called antigenic shift, is not the primary mechanism of mutation in the flu. It is the primary driver of pandemic strains of flu because it can lead to novel combinations of genes that encode the hemagglutinin and neuraminidase proteins. Antigenic drift is the primary driver of mutation each year that prompts us to constantly redesign vaccines. Antigenic drift is caused by the errors the flu viruses RNA dependent RNA polymerase makes while replicating the flus genome.

The real moral of the story...our immune systems need a certain amount of exposure to different pathogens to keep them primed. Even when different cold and/or flu strains circulate, many people have cross reactive immunity from having been exposed to prior similar strains. This cross reactive immunity  can make the illness milder than it would otherwise be if you had not had any previous similar exposures. I'm not saying that good hygiene is a bad thing, but a little exposure actually does the immune system some good in the long run. Hiding behind a mask in your basement for too long will eventually lead to you becoming much more ill from seasonal pathogens than you otherwise would have been if you had been exposed in small amounts during previous seasons.

The numbers are also suspect.

Pre-COVID, we assumed these symptoms meant "influenza" and didn't bother too much to analyze exactly which disease someone had if they presented with these symptoms (unless we had to, because the patient was not responding as expected) - we assumed they suffered from the predicted influenza strain for that season, based on those early six months.

Since COVID, there has been a nearly worldwide tendency to automatically categorize all patients presenting with these respiratory virus symptoms as "COVID", even in the absence of any test results. After all, "You have COVID symptoms, there's a COVID outbreak here, so why wouldn't it be COVID?"

So, we really don't know what the breakdown is among the total number of respiratory infections between COVID, various influenza strains, and "everything else" (including other coronavirus strains that aren't COVID).

It's really a lack of clear data, since we've tossed almost all the respiratory infection cases in 2020 and 2021 into one basket marked "COVID"... just as previously, we tended to toss them in a basket labeled "this season's influenza". The total number of infections hasn't really changed outside the normal variation of annual viral respiratory infections - just the ratio of what is influenza and what is something else, and we now are focused on that "something else" possibility when we normal focus on the "influenza" possibility.

That co-mingling of data makes an accurate statistical analysis very difficult. We cannot compare apples to apples, because we tossed all the apples, oranges, and lemons into one pile, and we're trying to guess how many of each we have. In previous years, we knew most of the fruits in the bin were going to be apples anyway, so it wasn't a problem - the answer would be "close enough for government work", even if there were some lemons and oranges inadvertently included. But it is a problem now because which way we jump for mitigation and intervention is determined by what the breakdown of patients with similar symptoms between COVID and influenza, and which strain of each they have.

Influenza virtually disappeared for the 2020/2021 season. Why? Of course, the typical knee-jerk conspiracy is "everything is just COVID now". But that's not true at all. In fact, heart disease and cancer were still number 1 and 2 in causes of death by a significant number (cancer was basically the same as in 2019 and heart disease saw its biggest jump in years). Ditto Alzheimers, diabetes, stroke etc. All similar but increased versus 2019.

But influenza really did go away, starting in March 2020. We were still testing for it, it's just that nobody was positive anymore. Test positivity was 0.2% during peak season in 2020/2021. That number is probably meaningless for most, but I can tell you that test positivity typically exceeds 20% during peak season. So essentially any given flu specimen was 100x more likely to test positive in 2019/2020 than in 2020/2021.

So why did flu disappear but not covid? I think it mostly boils down to the inherent infectiousness of each virus. For starters, the R0 of influenza is only 1.3 during peak season, compared to ~2.5-3 for OG covid and 5-8 for delta. This means that every person with influenza transmits it to 1.3 other people, on average, while the average person with COVID transmits it to at least twice as many people. Any R0 >1 = a growing number of cases and any R0 <1 = a declining number of cases. It's not very hard to conceive how you could implement measures which would drive influenza's R0 to less than 1 (meaning it goes away) while COVID's would stay above 1 (meaning it keeps proliferating, but less than it would without any measures at all). Let's say that masks reduced R0 of influenza and COVID by 0.5 each. That would drop flu's R0 to 0.8 (starts to disappear) while COVID's would still be 2+ (keeps growing).

And then there's the fact that they're different viruses and may spread differently. Influenza spreads through mostly large, heavy droplets. There is some evidence that COVID might be more prone to travel through smaller droplet nuclei. If that's the case, then the particles could stay suspended in the air longer and travel farther (so something like 6ft might work great for influenza, but not so well for COVID). It could also mean that masks are more effective for flu than influenza.

Lastly, there's population immunity to consider. Almost everyone in the world has been exposed to influenza, meaning there is some level of immunity that is likely always slowing the spread somewhat. SARS-COV-2, on the other hand, is a novel virus. In early 2020, there was essentially 0% population immunity and only 20-30% by then end of 2020 (in the US). Even today that number is probably under 80%, despite vaccination and over a hundred million infections. After delta is through, that number should be well over 80%.
